description: Recto elaborate historiated initial 'I' God created the world; also border decoration with dragon and bird
marks:
Inscription

Verso, in graphite, at upper right:
medium: Ink, gouache, and gold on parchment
text: The decorated letter I shows Christ pointing to a disk-shaped mappa mundi (map of the world), a medieval representation of the then known lands, encircled by the ocean. The image is apt, for this I introduces the phrase In principio fecit deus celum et terram (In the beginning God made heaven and earth), with which the book of Genesis opens. The musical notation—neumes (square notes) marked on a four-line staff—is typical of Gregorian plainchant, liturgical music that developed in the Western Church beginning in the 8th century. A leafy scroll climbs the border, rising from the dragon at the bottom and pecked on top by a bizarre bird. Sophisticated decoration, rich colors, and sinuous lines are characteristic of the so-called International Gothic style.
title: Salvator Mundi (Savior of the World), page from an Illuminated Antiphonary
